projects.name: Development of GBV referral pathway mechanisms and SOPs to strengthen national capacity for a coordinated multisectoral approach to prevent and respond to gender-based violence and harmful practices,
projects.description:
The GBV landscape in Mauritius is complex, shaped by socio-cultural norms, economic disparities, and legal frameworks. While the country has made strides in addressing GBV through legislation, policy development, and service provision, persistent challenges remain. These include underreporting of GBV cases, limited access to comprehensive services for survivors, and the need for increased awareness and prevention efforts.

projects.name: Monitoring and Evaluation framework, including supervision functions through elaboration of SOPs for Integrated Diseases Surveillance and Response strengthened
projects.description: Mauritius has made major leaps in the implementation of the Integrated Diseases Surveillance and Response Statregy with regular reports on the priority diseases to the WHO. An IDSR implementation is in place consisting of the adaptation and adoption of the 3rd IDSR guidelines, training of healthcare workers, and strengthening the surveillance system, through the establishment of the Public Health Emergency Operating Centre as the epitome of Early Warning Alert and Response System. projects.name: Building technical capacity for upscaling access to effective, gender sensitive and rapid initiation of HIV treatment for all people living with HIV
projects.description: Activities contributing to realisation of this sub-output were put on hold and re-scheduled to 2025. Instead activities related to development of a HIV Prevention Strategy and its operationalisation through a Masters Training of Trainers Course on HIV Prevention were prioritised. Both are essential and enabling factors to deliver the sub-output.

projects.name: National Health Emergency Response Operational Plan developed and implemented for strenghtening operational readiness  to assess and manage identified risks and vulnerabilities
projects.description: Mauritius and Rodrigues are Small Island Development States with heightened vulnerabilities to the effects of climate change. The Ministry of Health and Wellness in collaboration with WHO who provided the technical assistance in strategically assesing the risks to the respective countries through the STAR (strategic Toolkit for Assessing Risks). framework.name: PEOPLE

children.name: More people, especially youth, women and persons living with disabilities, have access to education and vocational training that enables them to access socioeconomic opportunities.
children.description: This output is required to support not only more inclusive human development, but also as the primary means by which Mauritius will accomplish economic transformation, for the benefits of its people and natural ecosystems. children.name: Safe, regular and orderly migration for inclusive socio-economic development is promoted
children.description: There were around 35,525 migrant workers (holders of valid work permits and certificate of exemption) in Mauritius as of March 2023 and the efficient functioning of the economy depends upon a steady stream of migrants. framework.name: PROSPERITY
framework.description: ADDRESSING STRUCTURAL VULNERABILITIES AND BOOSTING SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC TRANSFORMATION

children.name: Enhanced, innovation driven blue, green, circular, and digital economies that provides opportunities for all, in particular youth, women, persons living with disabilities and other vulnerable groups.
children.description: The potential of Mauritius’ blue, green, circular, and digital economies is still largely untapped. children.description: The analysis of the country’s vulnerabilities highlights the need for a strong focus on the water-energy-food-environment nexus60. children.name: The country’s biodiversity is protected and the pollution of ecosystems is curbed, allowing natural ecosystems to thrive.
children.description: Surrounded by coral reefs, Mauritius has significant marine biodiversity. This has important implications not only for national and international ecosystems, but also for the living  conditions and livelihoods of all communities.
